title: 108_hr1106
content:
The "Fremont-Madison Conveyance Act" defines terms like "District" and "Secretary" and involves the conveyance of facilities. The Secretary of the Interior is required to convey water distribution and drainage system components to the Fremont-Madison Irrigation District in Idaho as per a memorandum of agreement. If the conveyance is not completed, a report must be submitted. The District's water distribution and drainage system components are to be conveyed by the Secretary of the Interior to the Fremont-Madison Irrigation District in Idaho. If the conveyance is not completed by September 13, 2004, a report must be submitted to Congress explaining the delay. SEC. 4. COSTS. The Secretary requires the District to pay administrative costs and the net present value of remaining obligations for the conveyance of facilities. The Secretary requires the District to pay the net present value of remaining obligations for the conveyance of facilities, not exceeding $280,000, to be deposited into the Reclamation Fund. The Secretary will convey the Teton Exchange Wells, including a water permit and equipment, to the District. The water service contract between the Secretary and the District is extended until all conditions in the Act are met. Prior to conveyance, the Secretary must complete all environmental reviews and analyses as outlined in the Memorandum of Agreement. After conveyance, the United States will not be liable for damages except for acts of negligence committed prior to the conveyance date. This does not increase the liability beyond what is currently provided in chapter 171 of title 28, United States Code. SEC. 8. WATER SUPPLY TO DISTRICT LANDS: The acreage eligible for water from the Minidoka and Teton Basin Projects in the District is increased to include all current and annexed lands. This increase does not affect existing water contracts or state water law.

SEC. 9. DROUGHT MANAGEMENT PLANNING. Within 60 days of enactment, the Secretary will collaborate with stakeholders in the Henry's Fork watershed to initiate a drought management planning process for all water uses. A report with the final drought management plan must be submitted to Congress within 18 months. The Act does not affect existing rights of any person or the Shoshone-Bannock Tribes' water rights. Conveyances under the Act do not impact contracts or state laws regarding water use.
